definition: in a great rush/in a flurry
to get panicky/to lose one's head/(coll.) (after 得) unbearably/terribly

sentences.english: the pervading emotion is, I'd say, just stress and hurriedness.
sentences.chinese: 這裏的人們最普遍的感受還是壓力以及慌忙感。

sentences.english: Li Zhongzheng back and found the gates open, they hurriedly drove past view.
sentences.chinese: 李中正回城後發現城門大開，他們慌忙趕過去查看。

sentences.english: He escaped impetuously, like the wolf who finds his cage open.
sentences.chinese: 他象一頭狼，看見籠門開了，總要慌忙出逃。

sentences.english: Her week-day clothes had been tossed here and there in her haste.
sentences.chinese: 在慌忙中她把日常衣服扔得到處都是。

sentences.english: See how chutian plan to fail, hurriedly let teammates dropping bombs cover his escape.
sentences.chinese: 何楚天見計劃失敗，慌忙讓隊友扔炸彈掩護自己逃跑。

sentences.english: I cannot craft a thunderbolt. But God directs lightning, and nations cower and run in fear.
sentences.chinese: 我無法降下雷電，但神卻降下閃電，令列國慌忙逃躲。

sentences.english: He hurriedly thrust a gun into his pocket.
sentences.chinese: 他慌忙把一支槍塞進口袋。

sentences.english: Baekeland and his assistant dived for cover.
sentences.chinese: 貝克蘭和助手慌忙躲避。

sentences.english: Koreas thin film to pawn shops, hurriedly Xie Re snow to the hospital.
sentences.chinese: 韓疏影趕到典當行，慌忙把謝若雪送到了醫院。

sentences.english: While the multi-mode mother pulled out, flurried to repair the lotus cabinet.
sentences.chinese: 多模媽媽趁亞修拉出門，慌忙去了芙蓉閣。

sentences.english: Hwang hurried escape and hit the pole lying on the ground.
sentences.chinese: 黃某慌忙逃跑，撞上電線杆倒地。

sentences.english: The sound of John fussing about his breakfast drifted from the kitchen.
sentences.chinese: 從廚房裏傳來約翰在慌慌忙忙做早飯的聲音。

sentences.english: Liu flurried again and contact the police.
sentences.chinese: 劉慌忙又和警方取得聯繫。

sentences.english: All awakened from sleep, flurried cast out the door.
sentences.chinese: 衆人從睡夢中驚醒，慌忙趕出門外。

sentences.english: william never works rapidly. He always takes his time in everything that he does.
sentences.chinese: 威廉幹事大來不慌忙，他老是大大容容地做每一件事。

definition: rolling and crawling/trying frantically to escape (idiom)
to be just about to/to be on the point of
to lose one's head out of fear (idiom)
